<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  /* Cache 'daemon' here to avoid data races */
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->urh);
  mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME));

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  connection->urh->was_closed = true;
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via " \
                 "inter-thread communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: Other code in this function consists of simple assignments, mutex lock/unlock calls and function calls (e.g. caching 'daemon', MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(), setting flags, MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_()). Those statements do not introduce C control-flow constructs (if/while/for/do-switch) with controlling expressions and therefore are not relevant to Rule 14.3. There are no for/while/do-while loops or switch statements elsewhere in the function to inspect. The mhd_assert lines and the runtime if-condition were flagged because they either are control-like when the macro expands (mhd_assert may expand to control-flow) or include macros/functions (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_itc_activate_) that could expand/resolve to compile-time invariants in some build configurations; those expansions need to be examined to determine whether the controlling expressions are invariant. All other fragments are simple non-controlling expressions and do not need investigation for Rule 14.3.
